# Kuan Kheng Siang _v_ San Structural Construction Pte Ltd  

### \[2022\] SGMC 65

<table id="info-table"><tbody><tr class="info-row"><td class="txt-label" style="padding: 4px 0px; white-space: nowrap" valign="top">Case Number</td><td class="txt-body">Magistrate's Court Suit No 932 of 2022 (Summons No 3637 of 2022)</td></tr><tr class="info-row"><td class="txt-label" style="padding: 4px 0px; white-space: nowrap" valign="top">Decision Date</td><td class="txt-body">10 November 2022</td></tr><tr class="info-row"><td class="txt-label" style="padding: 4px 0px; white-space: nowrap" valign="top">Tribunal/Court</td><td class="txt-body">Magistrates Court</td></tr><tr class="info-row"><td class="txt-label" style="padding: 4px 0px; white-space: nowrap" valign="top">Coram</td><td class="txt-body">Liu Zeming</td></tr><tr class="info-row"><td class="txt-label" style="padding: 4px 0px; white-space: nowrap" valign="top">Counsel Name(s)</td><td class="txt-body">Lim Bee Li (Chevalier Law LLC) for the plaintiff</td></tr><tr class="info-row"><td class="txt-label" style="padding: 4px 0px; white-space: nowrap" valign="top">Parties</td><td class="txt-body">Kuan Kheng Siang — San Structural Construction Pte Ltd</td></tr></tbody></table>

Civil Procedure – Originating process – Writ – Extension of validity – Principles – Whether good reason to extend the writ

10 November 2022

### Deputy Registrar Liu Zeming:

1       Order 18 r 12(1A) of Rules of Court (2014 Rev Ed) (“**ROC 2014**”) requires a plaintiff in an action for personal injuries to serve a medical report together with his statement of claim (the “**SOC**”). What if the medical report is not available at the time when the statement of claim is required to be served? There are a number of options available to the plaintiff. Unfortunately, the Plaintiff in this case did not avail himself of any of these options. As a result, his writ expired before it was served and it was no longer viable to issue a new writ because the action has become limitation barred.

2       On 9 November 2022 I dismissed the Plaintiff’s application to renew his writ. These are the grounds of my decision.

## Background

3       The Plaintiff was injured in a road traffic accident on 2 February 2019. The accident was allegedly caused by the negligence of the Defendant’s employee who was, at the material time, driving the Defendant’s vehicle. On 3 February 2022, the Plaintiff commenced the present action against the Defendant to claim damages for his personal injuries.

4       The action was commenced by way of a generally-endorsed writ (see \[15\] below). According to the Plaintiff, this was so because the Plaintiff’s medical report was not available at the time the writ was issued. The medical report continued to be unavailable until around mid-September 2022. By then, the writ was no longer valid for service.

5       On 22 September 2022, the Plaintiff made the present application to extend the validity of the writ (the “**Application**”).

## The Application

6       The main (if not only) reason the Plaintiff proffered as to why the writ had been allowed to expire without any attempt at service was the unavailability of the Plaintiff’s medical report.

7       According to the first affidavit filed by the Plaintiff’s solicitor in support of the Application:

> (a)     The writ could not have been served on the Defendant earlier because the Plaintiff’s solicitors only managed to obtain a copy of the Plaintiff’s medical report in mid-September 2022.[\[note: 1\]](#Ftn_1)

> (b)     Although the medical report was issued in June 2022, it was mistakenly sent to the Plaintiff’s former solicitors (whose firm ceased operations in around April 2022), and was only handed over to the Plaintiff’s current solicitors “_sometime in mid September 2022_” by the administrators of the that law firm.[\[note: 2\]](#Ftn_2)

> (c)     The writ “_could not have been served earlier even if this_ \[Application\] _had been made and granted earlier as_ \[the Plaintiff’s solicitors\] _did not have sight of the Plaintiff’s medical report._ \[The Plaintiff’s solicitors\] _would not have been able to file the_ \[SOC\] _before the expiration of 14 days after the date the Defendant’s_ \[sic\] _would have to enter appearance_”.[\[note: 3\]](#Ftn_3)

8       As I found the initial explanations unsatisfactory, I directed the Plaintiff to address the following issues (and any other issue the Plaintiff wished to address) by way of further affidavit(s) and/or submissions:

> (a)     Why the Application was not or could not have been made before the validity of the writ expired;

> (b)     Why the writ (which was generally-endorsed) could not have been served on the Defendant without the SOC and/or the medical report; and

> (c)     Why an application for extension of time or stay could not have been made pursuant to Order 18 r 12(1B) of ROC 2014 if the medical report was not available at the time the SOC was required to be served.

9       On 5 October 2022, the Plaintiff’s solicitors filed a supplementary affidavit to address these issues.

10     Essentially, the Plaintiff’s explanation was that the Application was not filed earlier because the medical report was not available and the Plaintiff’s solicitor “_did not wish to make an application for renewal when_ \[she\] _did not have sight of the Plaintiff’s medical report_”.[\[note: 4\]](#Ftn_4) The Plaintiff’s solicitor also alluded to “_an issue taking over the matter…as the previous solicitor in charge passed away in February 2022_”,[^5] although the relevance of that statement was unclear to me since I was not at all concerned with the conduct of the matter prior to the filing of the writ.

11     As to why the Plaintiff could not serve the generally-endorsed writ on the Defendant first, the Plaintiff’s solicitor explained that she “_did not want to serve the SOC without the medical report because it would be_ \[sic\] _essential piece of evidence for the Plaintiff’s personal injury claim. The Defendant would also have required the Plaintiff’s medical report to properly defend against the Plaintiff’s claim_”.[\[note: 6\]](#Ftn_6) Another reason cited by the Plaintiff’s solicitor was that “\[c\]_osts consequences may also result if_ \[the Plaintiff\] _file to amend the Writ without obtaining the medical report_”.[^7] The Plaintiff’s solicitor did not elaborate on what “_costs consequences_” or amendment of the writ was being referred to.

12     Lastly, the Plaintiff’s solicitor offered an uninvited apology “_for not first serving the Writ without the medical report given that the Court may order, if it thinks fit, to dispense with the requirement for the medical report_”.[\[note: 8\]](#Ftn_8) However, the Plaintiff’s solicitor explained that she did not wish to seek such dispensation as she “_believe_\[d\] _that the medical report would ultimately be necessary_” and it was therefore appropriate to wait for the medical report before proceeding with the Plaintiff’s claim.[^9]

13     In conclusion, the Plaintiff’s solicitor reminded the court that if the Application was dismissed, “_the Plaintiff’s action would have been time barred and the Defendant would have gotten away scot_ \[sic\] _free when the Defendant was the one who hit the Plaintiff and caused him injury_”.[\[note: 10\]](#Ftn_10)

## My Decision

### The “generally-endorsed writ” and the “medical report”

14     In order to understand the Plaintiff’s explanation as to why the writ was not served, it is necessary to first explain the relationship between a “generally-endorsed writ” and the “medical report” which the Plaintiff had referred to.

15     A writ of summons (often referred to more simply as a “writ”) is the formal document by which a civil action is commenced in court under ROC 2014. Every writ issued has a “validity period”. This refers to the period within which the writ is valid _for the purposes of service_ on a defendant. Under ROC 2014, a writ is valid in the first stance for 6 months for service in Singapore, and 12 months for service outside of Singapore. If service cannot be effected within this initial validity period, the plaintiff may apply to the court for an order to extend the validity period of the writ. This extension of the validity period of the writ is sometimes also referred to as a “renewal” of the writ, denoting that the writ on which the initial validity period had expired has been “renewed” for a specified period, and is capable of being validly served within that extended period.

16     Before a writ is issued, it must be endorsed either with a SOC or an “endorsement of claim”. A SOC is a pleading and a full and proper statement of the plaintiff’s claim, with particulars. An “endorsement of claim” on the other hand refers to a concise statement of the nature of the claim made or the relief or remedy sought in the action. A writ which is only endorsed with an endorsement of claim (and not a SOC) is commonly referred to as a “generally-endorsed writ”.

17     A generally-endorsed writ is as good as any other writ for the purposes of service. Like any other writ, it must be served personally on each defendant: see Order 10 r 1 of ROC 2014. Thereafter, the defendant served with a generally-endorsed writ must file a memorandum of appearance within 8 (if served in Singapore) or 21 days (if served outside of Singapore) after service of the writ if he/she wishes to defend the claim: see Order 12 rrs 1 and 4. Up until this stage, the SOC does not need to be served. Under Order 18 r 1 of ROC 2014, for a generally-endorsed writ, the SOC need only be served on the defendant within 14 days _after_ that defendant enters an appearance.

18     When the plaintiff serves the SOC, the plaintiff must ensure that the SOC complies with the requirements under Order 18 of ROC 2014. Specifically, under Order 18 r 12(1A), a plaintiff in an action for personal injuries must serve a medical report together with the SOC. The “medical report” in this context refers to a report substantiating all the personal injuries alleged in the SOC which the plaintiff proposes to adduce in evidence as part of his case at trial: see Order 18 r 12(1C) of ROC 2014. Such a medical report will in practice operate as the detailed particulars of the personal injuries alleged by the plaintiff in the SOC and may be updated with fresh reports as the injuries develop: see _Singapore Civil Procedure 2021 vol 1_ (Cavinder Bull general ed) (Sweet & Maxwell, 2021) (the “**White Book**”) at \[18/12/53\] and \[18/12/54\].

19     Sometimes, however, the medical report may not be ready or available at the time when the SOC is required to be served, or at all. In such circumstances, the SOC must still be served. However, Order 18 r 12(1B) of ROC 2014 permits the court to:

> (a)     specify the period of the time within which the medical report is to be provided; or

> (b)     make such order as it thinks fit, including an order dispensing with the requirements in Order 18 r 12(1A) or staying the proceedings.

20     In other words, if the medical report is not available, or not yet available when the SOC is required to be served, the plaintiff should still proceed to serve the SOC _without_ the medical report, but at the same time (or even prior to such service) make an application under Order 18 r 12(1B) to seek the appropriate order relating to the provision of the medical report. What may be appropriate will depend on the circumstances. For example, if the medical report is forth-coming, it would make sense to seek a short extension of time for the provision of the medical report, and a corresponding extension of time for the defence to be filed. Where, however, the plaintiff expects a significant delay in the provision of the medical report, a stay of the proceedings may be more suitable.

21     The relationship between the generally-endorsed writ, the SOC and the medical report required under Order 18 r 12(1A) of ROC 2014 may be summarised as follows:

![](data:image;base64,)

22     To be clear, the positioned outlined above is with respect to ROC 2014. The timelines and procedures under Rules of Court 2021 (“**ROC 2021**”) are different, and it would be unsafe to assume that the same applies under ROC 2021.

### Is the unavailability of the medical report a “good reason” not to serve the writ?

23     In deciding whether to renew the writ, the court must first be satisfied that there is a good reason to do so: see _The “Ching Ho” and another vessel_ <span class="citation">\[2001\] SGHC 259</span> at \[21\]. This question is inextricably bound with whether the plaintiff had good reason(s) for failing to serve the writ during the original period of validity: see _The “Nur Allya”_ <span class="citation">\[2018\] SGHCR 12</span> at \[36(b)\]. If there are good reasons, the court goes on to consider whether to exercise its discretion in favour of renewal by considering all the circumstances of the case. In this regard, a writ will not normally be renewed so as to deprive the defendant of the accrued benefit of a limitation period. Accordingly, where the application for renewal is made _after_ the writ has expired and _after_ the expiry of the relevant limitation period, the plaintiff must not only show good reason for the renewal, but must give a satisfactory explanation for the failure to apply for renewal before the validity period of the writ expired: see the White Book at \[6/4/3\].

24     In this case, the unavailability of the Plaintiff’s medical report was simply _not_ a good reason for failing to serve the writ within its validity period. Neither did it excuse the failure to apply for renewal before the validity period of the writ expired.

25     It ought to be apparent from the explanation at \[17\] to \[20\] above that the Plaintiff could and should have served the generally-endorsed writ on the Defendant within the initial 6-month validity period of the writ, even if the medical report was not yet available. The absence of the medical report did not impose any legal or practical impediment to the service of the generally-endorsed writ on the Defendant.

26     In this regard, the Plaintiff solicitor’s explanation that she “_did not want to serve the SOC without the medical report because it would be_ \[sic\] _essential piece of evidence for the Plaintiff’s personal injury claim_ \[and\] \[t\]_he Defendant would also have required the Plaintiff’s medical report to properly defend against the Plaintiff’s claim_”[\[note: 11\]](#Ftn_11) completely missed the point. It was only the generally-endorsed writ that was required to be served within the validity period of the writ. The SOC and the medical report were only required to be served at a later stage in accordance with ROC 2014, and the service of these documents need not be done within the validity period of the writ. The Plaintiff’s decision to defer service of the writ until after the medical report was received was therefore inexplicable.

27     What the Plaintiff could and should have done was to serve the generally-endorsed writ on the Defendant within the validity period of the writ. Thereafter, if the Defendant enters an appearance and if the medical report was still not ready, the Plaintiff should either file a SOC without the medical report, but with an application under Order 18 r 12(1B), or make an application for an extension of time to serve the SOC.

28     The perceived need by the plaintiff’s solicitors to serve a SOC with the writ has been held _not_ to be a good reason to extend time for the writ: see the White Book at \[6/4/3\], paragraph (10). In fact, in _Sarkir Babu v Graphic-Tech Construction_ <span class="citation">\[2021\] SGDC 216</span>, the learned District Judge held that the need to procure a medical report was similarly _not_ a good reason for delaying service of the writ (at \[23\] and \[24\]):

> Plaintiff Counsel contended that time was needed to procure a medical report on the Plaintiff’s injuries, which report was in turn necessary for preparing the \[SOC\].

> I did not agree that this constituted good reason for delaying service of the writ. **There was no need for the Plaintiff to have the \[SOC\] on hand, when serving the writ. Given that the lapse of the limitation was looming, he could have simply served the writ first and then seek an extension of time for servicing the SOC**.

(emphasis added)

29     This was exactly the case here.

30     At the _barest minimum_, the Plaintiff should have filed his application for renewal before the validity of the writ expired. If that had been done, then at least the Plaintiff would not face the same difficulties with a renewal depriving the Defendant of an accrued benefit of a limitation period. Why the Plaintiff would decide to wait for the medical report before making the application for renewal when the Plaintiff was fully aware of the expired limitation period and the looming expiry of the writ was even more inexplicable to me.

31     Accordingly, I could not accept that the Plaintiff had any good reason for failing to serve the writ during its initial validity period or that there was any other good reason to extend time.

32     In these circumstances, there was no need for me to go on to consider the balance of hardship between the parties and whether the court’s discretion should be exercised in favour of renewal. The evidence and submissions on this point was in any event scant, and the only argument raised by the Plaintiff’s solicitor was that “_the Plaintiff’s action would have been time barred and the Defendant would have gotten away scot_ \[sic\] _free_”[\[note: 12\]](#Ftn_12) if this Application was dismissed. With respect, if this was so, it was entirely the Plaintiff’s own doing. In any event, the fact that the Plaintiff’s action would have been time barred is a factor militating _against_ renewal, because doing so would deprive a defendant of an accrued limitation defence: see _The “Ching Ho” and another vessel_ <span class="citation">\[2001\] SGHC 259</span> at \[20\]. I therefore could not see how this assists the Plaintiff.

## Conclusion

33     In the circumstances, I dismissed the Application.

34     The reminder from the Plaintiff’s solicitor that “_the Plaintiff’s action would have been time barred and the Defendant would have gotten away scot_ \[sic\] _free_”[\[note: 13\]](#Ftn_13) if the writ was not renewed was one that should have been sounded before the validity of the writ ran out. In this decision I have outlined the options available to a plaintiff who may face difficulties in procuring the medical report in a personal injury claim (see \[20\] and \[27\] above). The bottom-line is that the plaintiff in such a situation _should not defer service of the writ_ with an expectation that the writ would be renewed when the medical report becomes available. That may turn out to be a costly mistake.

35     No order was made as to costs for this Application.

* * *

[\[note: 1\]](#Ftn_1_1)Affidavit of Wong Zhen Yang dated 22 September 2022 (“**1st Aff**”) at \[5\].
